#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=DRINK
#Text=Tom Foster came to Winesburg from Cincinnati when he was still young and could get many new impressions .

#Text=His grandmother had been raised on a farm near the town and as a young girl had gone to school there when Winesburg was a village of twelve or fifteen houses clustered about a general store on the Trunion Pike .
#Text=What a life the old woman had led since she went away from the frontier settlement and what a strong , capable little old thing she was !
#Text=She had been in Kansas , in Canada , and in New York City , traveling about with her husband , a mechanic , before he died .
#Text=Later she went to stay with her daughter , who had also married a mechanic and lived in Covington , Kentucky , across the river from Cincinnati .
#Text=Then began the hard years for Tom Foster 's grandmother .
#Text=First her son-in-law was killed by a policeman during a strike and then Tom 's mother became an invalid and died also .
#Text=The grandmother had saved a little money , but it was swept away by the illness of the daughter and by the cost of the two funerals .
#Text=She became a half worn-out old woman worker and lived with the grandson above a junk shop on a side street in Cincinnati .
#Text=For five years she scrubbed the floors in an office building and then got a place as dish washer in a restaurant .
#Text=Her hands were all twisted out of shape .
#Text=When she took hold of a mop or a broom handle the hands looked like the dried stems of an old creeping vine clinging to a tree .
#Text=The old woman came back to Winesburg as soon as she got the chance .
#Text=One evening as she was coming home from work she found a pocket-book containing thirty-seven dollars , and that opened the way .
#Text=The trip was a great adventure for the boy .
#Text=It was past seven o'clock at night when the grandmother came home with the pocket-book held tightly in her old hands and she was so excited she could scarcely speak .
#Text=She insisted on leaving Cincinnati that night , saying that if they stayed until morning the owner of the money would be sure to find them out and make trouble .

#Text=Tom , who was then sixteen years old , had to go trudging off to the station with the old woman , bearing all of their earthly belongings done up in a worn-out blanket and slung across his back .
#Text=By his side walked the grandmother urging him forward .

#Text=Her toothless old mouth twitched nervously , and when Tom grew weary and wanted to put the pack down at a street crossing , she snatched it up and if he had not prevented would have slung it across her own back .
#Text=When they got into the train and it had run out of the city she was as delighted as a girl and talked as the boy had never heard her talk before .

#Text=All through the night as the train rattled along , the grandmother told Tom tales of Winesburg and of how he would enjoy his life working in the fields and shooting wild things in the woods there .
#Text=She could not believe that the tiny village of fifty years before had grown into a thriving town in her absence , and in the morning when the train came to Winesburg did not want to get off .

#Text=It may be hard for you here ,  she said , and then the train went on its way and the two stood confused , not knowing where to turn , in the presence of Albert Longworth , the Winesburg baggage master .

column1: #Text=Mrs. White was sick of hired girls and snatched at the chance to get hold of the old city woman .
#Text=She furnished a room for the boy Tom upstairs in the barn .
#Text=" He can mow the lawn and run errands when the horses do not need attention , " she explained to her husband .
#Text=Tom Foster was rather small for his age and had a large head covered with stiff black hair that stood straight up .
#Text=The hair emphasized the bigness of his head .
#Text=His voice was the softest thing imaginable , and he was himself so gentle and quiet that he slipped into the life of the town without attracting the least bit of attention .
#Text=One could not help wondering where Tom Foster got his gentleness .
#Text=In Cincinnati he had lived in a neighborhood where gangs of tough boys prowled through the streets , and all through his early formative years he ran about with tough boys .
#Text=For a while he was a messenger for a telegraph company and delivered messages in a neighborhood sprinkled with houses of prostitution .
#Text=The women in the houses knew and loved Tom Foster and the tough boys in the gangs loved him also .
#Text=He never asserted himself .
#Text=That was one thing that helped him escape .
#Text=In an odd way he stood in the shadow of the wall of life , was meant to stand in the shadow .

#Text=He saw the men and women in the houses of lust , sensed their casual and horrible love affairs , saw boys fighting and listened to their tales of thieving and drunkenness , unmoved and strangely unaffected .
